div1.p: DEPARTMENT OF STATE APR 28 1888 RECEIVED
No. 4.
Consulate General of the United States Monrovia, March 17th 1888
Mr B. Y. Payne to the Assistant Secretary of State.
Subject.
Receipt of Despatch No. 10

Sir. I have the honor to acknolwedge the receipt of your No 10 Diplomatic series of December 14th 1887 with enclosures relative to the Liberian laborer at Panama: also, your printed circular relative to the Resolutions of the International Meridian Conference tv, and bug to say, that I immediately transmitted to the Government Government
Government of Liberia, copies of same, and take plasure in enclosing to you, Secretary Barclay's replies.
I have the honor to be, Sir, your obedient Servant
Beverly Y. Payne Act'g Vice General Conl.
Hon. G. L. Rive Asst Secy of State
Enclosure, Secretary Barclay Replica refered to Nos 1 & 2.
Copy No. 1
Department of State Monrovia, March 16th 1888 Liberia, W. C. A.

Sir: I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your comunication of the 24th ult., transmitting to me by order of the Secretary of State of the United States a copy of a despatch from the Consul General of the United States at Panama, in regard to reported disturbances or disorders on the lines of the Panama Canal, in which Liberian citizens are said to have been concerned.
In reply Sir, permit me to inform you that the copy of the important despatch above cities have been with its enclosure enclosure

enclosures carefully perused by my Governmnet, and after a due consideration have been given to the matter, it is the opinion of the Liberian government that the inpression of Consul General Adamson, as to the countries to which the so called Liberian rally belong, are correct, for the following reasons.

1st It is not the custom of Kroomen or other natives of Liberia, when shipping to work in a foreign country, or even to work along the Coast to take their war customs with them. The fact being that they take away next to nothing but live to return in in

in opposite condition. Furthermore the Liberian Natives shipping for work at Panama, had their outfit of clothing furnished by the Company's Agent, at the time of entering into the service of the company.

2nd The natives of Liberia are notorious for their peaceful and orderly demeanor, which away from their homes and in a~ foreign country, they are as a general such very careful to-- avoid any conflict with the laws of the country in which they are residing, which would tend to curtail their liberty of departure at the period, fixed for their return to their homes. I have

I have therefore to request, that you will be kind enough to convey to the Government of the United States, the thanks of that of Liberia for the unabated interest it continues to exhibit for the affairs of Liberian citizens at present residing in the Isthmus of Panama, and, also convey to your Government the conclusion in which this Department is in accord with Consul General Adamson, that the parties who were said to have been engaged in the commission of disorder at Panama, are not natives of Liberia, but hiding to the more intractable tribes to the North and South of Liberia
B. Y. Payne, Esq., U.S. Act'g Vice Consul General, Monrovia
Liberian territory, and, living under either French or English, funsdiction.
I have the honor to be Sir Your obediant Servant
E. J. Barclay
Department of State Monrovia, March 16th 1888 Liberia, W. C. A.

Sir: I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of that portion of your Despatch of the 24th alt., with enclosures in the subject of the Resolutions of the International Meridian Conference which was held in Washington D. C. during the month of October 1884, and to inform you that the Report alluded to in your said Despatch is having the consideration of the Liberian Government.
I have the honor to be Sir Your obedient Servant
E. J. Barclay
